thread.title: Apple deletes 250 apps over fears Chinese company is using them to steal your personal information
thread.title_full: Apple deletes 250 apps over fears Chinese company is using them to steal your personal information - Mirror Online

author: Jeff Parsons
title: Apple deletes 250 apps over fears Chinese company is using them to steal your personal information
text:
Apple has deleted more than 250 apps from the app store over fears Chinese advertisers are using them to steal personal information .
According to the world's most valuable tech company, the tainted apps were downloaded by an estimated one million users.
Apple believes Youmi, a Chinese advertiser, provided a tweaked software development kit (SDK) to developers who then unwittingly developed the apps.
The apps would then provide Youmi with personal information such as Apple IDs (used for buying apps and media) and serial numbers of iPhones and iPads.
"We've identified a group of apps that are using a third-party advertising SDK, developed by Youmi, a mobile advertising provider, that uses private APIs to gather private information, such as user email addresses and device identifiers, and route data to its company server," explained Apple in a statement.
Rex
"This is a violation of our security and privacy guidelines. The apps using Youmi's SDK will be removed from the App Store and any new apps submitted to the App Store using this SDK will be rejected."
Apple hasn't explicitly named which apps were responsible for stealing the personal data.
But it follows news that Facebook will now alert users when "government-sponsored" hackers target their profiles .
In a blog post, Alex Stamos, chief security officer at Facebook, said the social network will flag up "targeted attacks".
"Starting today, we will notify you if we believe your account has been targeted or compromised by an attacker suspected of working on behalf of a nation-state," he said.
Anyone who comes under attack will be given a warning, advising them their account has been compromised.
This isn't the first time Apple has had to defend its online store against a Chinese threat. In September, tainted Chinese apps were loaded on through the Xcode vulnerability .
